awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Research, Synthesis, and Knowledge Transfer in a Changing Arctic: Science Support for the Study of Environmental Arctic Change (SEARCH)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Arctic is undergoing dramatic, accelerating environmental change, resulting in impacts on local, regional and global scales. Improved understanding of the present and probable future state of the arctic environment is important for a wide range of stakeholders, including arctic residents, the private sector, agencies and decision-makers. To develop and convey this understanding to decision makers, an interdisciplinary research program is needed that engages with stakeholders to provide science-based answers to stakeholder questions, and the Study of Arctic Environmental Change (SEARCH) is well positioned to serve this function. This project will build a support structure to enable SEARCH to serve the needs of the scientific community and agencies. The new research coordination structure will coordinate science, exchange knowledge and tools between science and stakeholders, drive scientific syntheses, and connect scientists and stakeholders to answer questions about arctic change. The new structure will ensure that its activities have societal benefit, and foster two-way communication of research findings and information needs. Proposed activities include knowledge exchange workshops that will facilitate networking between stakeholders and scientists, and stakeholders will be included in other synthesis research activities, meetings and conferences. A set of activities focused on the theme "Arctic Futures 2050" will frame scientific findings in a way that can help decision-makers plan for the future. All of these activities will lead to development of research products that address societal priorities and can help inform policy. 

SEARCH will facilitate research in response to scientific priorities and stakeholder questions about complex arctic change. This project will improve understanding, advance prediction, and explore the consequences of changing arctic sea ice; document and improve understanding of how degradation of near-surface permafrost will affect arctic and global systems; and improve predictions of future land-ice loss and its impacts on sea level. An additional overarching goal will be to analyze societal and policy implications of these arctic environmental changes, and a set of activities will be undertaken to integrate findings across all the thematic goals. These goals will be achieved by facilitating research across disciplines, scales and among agencies; advancing scientific synthesis of data, model output and expert projections; creating networks of people and research groups that promote efficiencies and scientific discovery; developing tools useful to stakeholders and decision-makers; and enhancing research coordination.

por.por_cntn:
For the past six years, the Study of Environmental Arctic Change (SEARCH) extended the reach of Arctic research by connecting experts across disciplines and knowledge systems, facilitating syntheses, and broadening the venues in which researchers shared their knowledge.

 Over 800 scientists, Indigenous experts, and stakeholders came together in SEARCH and collaboratively:

 1.     improved understanding, advanced prediction, and described the consequences of diminishing Arctic sea ice,

 2.     documented and improved understanding of how degradation of near-surface permafrost is affecting the Arctic and other regions,

 3.     improved predictions of future glacier and ice sheet loss and the global impacts on sea level, and

 4.     analyzed societal and policy implications of Arctic environmental changes and disseminated the analyses in publications and briefs for policy makers.

 

Understanding, prediction, and consequences of sea ice loss

SEARCH sponsored communications workshops, press and Congressional briefings, as well as exchanges of knowledge between scientific, Indigenous, and decision-making experts that deepened understanding, advanced predictive skills, and made clearer the consequences of diminishing sea ice in the Arctic. Technical, multi-disciplinary, and lay publications explained the connections between sea ice loss and extreme weather events, diminishing glaciers and ice sheets, capabilities and limitations of predictive models, as well as impacts on Arctic communities and commercial and subsistence fisheries. SEARCH also gave voice to Indigenous observations of sea ice loss and the consequences by facilitating publication of Indigenous authors in the Arctic Report Card and by co-producing with the Bering Sea Elders? Group a video series, After the Ice, which presented Indigenous knowledge and is available on the Public Broadcasting Service?s YouTube channel (https://www.pbs.org/show/after-ice/).

Documenting and understanding processes and consequences of permafrost thaw

For the past six years, SEARCH supported the Permafrost Carbon Network, a collaboration of international scientists pooling their knowledge and collaboratively identifying the most important questions concerning carbon emissions from northern soils. Twice each year, the collaborators met, shared results, and collaboratively outlined future research. SEARCH raised funding for an additional workshop that facilitated important conversations and harmonized the research of scientists studying methane on land, in the ocean, and in the atmosphere. SEARCH research on permafrost informed policy decisions through publications in influential scientific journals, reports of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, policy briefs, and publications aimed at general audiences.

Predicting future melt of glaciers and ice sheets and the impacts on sea level

A SEARCH team concentrating on Arctic glaciers and ice sheets also focused the collaboration efforts of academic, governmental agencies (municipal, state, Federal, and international), and non-governmental researchers. That team also informed policy and economic decisions through technical, multi-disciplinary, policy, and lay publications. They provided expert testimony to the U.S. Congress, public utilities agencies, and others planning for continuing sea level rise. They took the lead in SEARCH?s synthesis of the combined consequences?in the Arctic and beyond?of diminishing glaciers, ice sheets, sea ice, and permafrost.

Societal and policy implications of Arctic environmental changes

The unprecedented magnitude and pace of environmental changes in the Arctic necessitate responses informed by holistic understanding. SEARCH contributed to such understanding by integrating the knowledge of our action teams, other scientists, policy experts, and?to a certain extent?Indigenous experts. That integration was manifest in SEARCH contributions to policy briefings (e.g., the Arctic Answers science briefs), synthesis reports (e.g., the National Climate Assessment, IPCC assessments, and a SEARCH synthesis published in Earth?s Future), cross-disciplinary workshops (e.g., the NSF-sponsored workshop on Forging Collaboration and Encouraging Research on the Arctic Economy, a special session of the National Adaptation Forum, and collaboration with the NASA Sea Level Team); international convenings (e.g., presentations at meetings of the International Arctic Science Committee and the Global Council for Science and the Environment as well as a SEARCH keynote address to the first Arctic Science Ministerial); and a great many public lectures.

SEARCH also furthered integration of knowledge about the changing Arctic by convening 40 scientific, Indigenous, and decision-making experts in an international scenarios workshop. The results of that effort helped inform our capstone conference, Arctic Futures 2050, wherein over 400 scientists, Indigenous People, and policy makers from around the Arctic discussed the state of understanding and ways to accelerate Arctic research while making the enterprise more inclusive. The reach of the conference was extended through live-streaming, posting professionally produced videos of the presentations to the SEARCH website, and through a reflective conference report.

The Arctic Futures 2050 conference was unique in relying primarily on discussions by small panels each comprising a scientist, an Indigenous expert, and a policy maker. SEARCH raised substantial funding to ensure that Indigenous Peoples from around the Arctic were well represented. The conference format and inclusivity yielded novel insights and highlighted the value of diverse voices in the research enterprise. SEARCH and other participants left with a deeper understanding of the need for complex collaborations of diverse experts.
